pages.title: Redstone Port
pages.text: The Redstone Port allow you to automate your Reactor using Redstone.$(br2)Open the Port graphical interface to configure it. You can then choose between three input settings (that listen for a Redstone signal) and six output ones (that emit a Redstone signal).

$(bold)Input settings$()$(br2)Perform one of the following actions when a Redstone signal is received$(br2)$(li)$(o)On / Off :$() turn the Reactor on or off depending on the signal received$(li)$(o)Eject Waste :$() eject waste material to Access Ports in outlet mode$(li)$(o)Control Rods Insertion :$() set the insertion percentage of all Control Rods in the Reactor.

$(bold)Output settings$()$(br2)Emit a Redstone signal when one of the following conditions are meet$(br2)$(li)$(o)Casing Temp :$() the heat of the Reactor Casing is above or below a given temperature$(li)$(o)Fuel Temp :$() the heat of the Reactor Core is above or below a given temperature$(li)$(o)Fuel Mix :$() the Fuel Richness percentile is above or below a given value

$(li)$(o)Fuel Amount :$() the amount of fuel available is above or below a given value$(li)$(o)Waste Amount :$() the amount of waste available is above or below a given value.$(li)$(o)Energy Amount :$() the amount of energy stored in the internal energy buffer is above or below a given value.
You will usually need two or more Redstone Port to fully automate a Reactor.$(br2)For more complex automations, check the $(l:reactor/part-computerport)Computer Port$(/l).
$(l)Mandatory:$() no$(br)$(l)Valid positions:$() any face (not on frame)$(br)$(l)Graphical interface:$() yes
